repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Social Security Special
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the Second Social
            Security Sector Adjustment Loan Project is rated as
            satisfactory. The lessons learned from this project include:
            a) A programmatic approach to support pension reform could
            be relevant for pension reform since it allows for a series
            of modular or sequential reform packages. It controls the
            risk of non-performance by conditioning future programs
            based on current performance. b) Protecting key social
            protection sectors during adjustment operations may yield
            positive payoffs in terms of improved poverty indicators
            following the aftermath of economic shocks. c) Successful
            pension reform requires substantial dialogue, discussion and
            debate with local counterparts, policymakers, and experts.
            Toward that end, the present pension reform agenda in Brazil
            took its roots through a series of seminars, debates, and
            training sessions organized jointly by the Borrower and the
            Bank. d) Technical assistance and knowledge dissemination
            are very effective de-politicizing tools. The widespread
            training of Bank's Pension Reform Options Simulation
            Toolkit - a toolkit developed by the Bank for analyzing
            pension reform - in Brazil stirred debate and dialogue as
            the structural weaknesses of these plans became evident to
            policymakers, experts, and other relevant stakeholders.

Brazil - Second Social Security Special

693139.trustfund:
TF025825-PHRD-SECOND SOCIAL SECURITY
            SPECIAL SECTOR ADJ. LOAN

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Second Social Security Special
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Social Security Special
            Sector Adjustment Loan Project, aims at supporting the
            second phase of the reform program in Brazil, emphasizing
            the implementation of additional reforms to achieve
            financial, and actuarial balances in the pension system for
            private sector workers, in accordance with the
            Constitutional Amendment. To this effect, legislation has
            been enacted, defining the new basis for benefit
            calculations for retirees, respecting the principle of
            fiscal balance, to take place in the next three years.
            Further reforms, include the drafting of legislation, and
            issuance of regulations to strengthen the regulatory
            framework of the pension system for private sector workers,
            and of complementary pension funds in the restructuring of
            the National Institute of Social Security. The adoption of
            this new formula for private sector workers, will reduce the
            deficit of the system, and contribute to fiscal adjustments,
            which will in turn improve rapid growth, and low inflation
            prospects, paramount for poverty reduction. However,
            moderate risks remain, since it is common that the adoption
            of this new benefit formula, could be subjected to legal
            challenges. But the strong commitment to the reform program
            suggests this risk is minimal, furthermore, when some of
            these reforms have already been approved by the Chamber.
